results.title: What's in a shadow?: Finding directions
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the measurement of shadows throughout the day to determine the sun’s position and how to use this knowledge to find one’s direction. Also defines the earth’s relationship to the sun.

results.title: What's in a sandpit?
results.creator_credit: Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: No 2 in a series of in-service science education films produced for the Curriculum and research Branch for discussion purposes. This film is to be used to introduce the new Primary Science course. A group of teachers discuss how they might plan work for their pupils. Various problems are discussed. From the “Science in Primary School” series.

results.title: What's in a rainbow?: making scientific models
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science fact and fun”.
Shows how to create a scientific model of a rainbow using a hose, stressing that the angle of the sun in the sky is an important factor in determining whether or not a rainbow appears. Introduces the ideas of reflection and refraction. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: What's happening to me?
results.creator_credit: Greg ingram, Stephen Smallwood, Steve Walsh and Consolidated Productions
results.brief_description: An honest, sympathetic and humorous animated presentation of the main changes occuring in females and males during puberty. Covers the growth of pubic and other body hair, menstruation, readiness for reproduction, growth of breasts, masturbation, erections, wet dreams, voice changes, pimples, different rates of onset of puberty and physical diferences between those of the same age and sex. Based on the book by Peter Mayle and Arthur Robins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg ingram, Stephen Smallwood, Steve Walsh and Consolidated Productions

results.title: What's for lunch?
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris, Rob McCubbin, Trevor Lunn and Channel 7 for Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Education

results.title: What's cooking?
results.creator_credit: Damian Brown, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Presents a humorous look at the health problems which abound in the unhygienic kitchen and shows how to overcome these through following sanitary procedures. The film covers proper refridgeration of food, observation of shelf life of food products, how to recognise blown cans and the need to avoid using the same utensils for cooked and uncooked food. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Damian Brown, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation

results.title: What's causing the problem? (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Improving Performance”.
The second step in performance appraisal is the need to identify and agree on the cause of the work problem before discussing solutions. Examples of no agreement on cause are followed by Peter Quarry demonstrating clear agreement on cause.

results.title: What's an Accountant?
results.creator_credit: Neil McClure, CPA Australia and Production Group
results.brief_description: Tania Lacey introduces a program designed to encourage viewers to consider the possibility of a career in accounting. Discusses common sterotypes of accountants, the prerequisites for an accountancy career and the diverse range of employment opportunities. Wherever you may wish to work - “Accountancy can take you there!”
